model

Interface IFacade

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    Facade

    public interface IFacade
    Implement this interface to connect your code to the user interface.
    • Your class for representing ships should implement the interface IShip. For example, if your class is named ShipImpl , then the header of that class should look as follows:

      class ShipImpl implements IShip { ... }

      Consult the Java tutorial for more information on interfaces.
    • Connect your class to the user interface by creating a class named Facade that implements IFacade. The header of that class should look as follows:

      class Facade implements IFacade { ... }

      Each method defined in the interface IFacade must be implemented by the class Facade. For example, the implementation of getX should call a method of the given ship to retrieve its x-coordinate.
    • Modify the code between <begin> and <end> in Asteroids.java: replace new asteroids.model.Facade() with new yourpackage.Facade().
    • You may assume that only null or objects returned by createShip are passed to getX, getY, move, etc. This means that you can safely cast non-null parameters of type IShip to your own class type.
    • Methods in this interface are allowed to throw only ModelException. No other exception types are allowed. This exception can be thrown only if calling a method of your Ship class with the given parameters would violate a precondition or if the method of your Ship class throws an exception (if so, wrap the exception in a ModelException). ModelException should not be used anywhere outside of your Facade implementation.
    • The rules described above and the documentation described below for each method apply only to the class implementing IFacade. Your class for representing robots should follow the rules described in the assignment.
    • Do not modify the signatures of the methods defined in this interface. You can however add additional methods, as long as these additional methods do not overload the existing ones. Each additional method must be implemented in your class Facade.
    • Your class implementing IFacade should offer a default constructor.

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      IShip createShip()
      Create a new ship with a default position, velocity, radius and direction.
      IShip createShip(double x, double y, double xVelocity, double yVelocity, double radius, double angle)
      Create a new non-null ship with the given position, velocity, radius and angle (in radians).
      double[] getCollisionPosition(IShip ship1, IShip ship2)
      Return the first position where ship1 and ship2 collide, or null if they never collide.
      double getDirection(IShip ship)
      Return the direction of ship (in radians).
      double getDistanceBetween(IShip ship1, IShip ship2)
      Return the distance between ship1 and ship2.
      double getRadius(IShip ship)
      Return the radius of ship.
      double getTimeToCollision(IShip ship1, IShip ship2)
      Return the number of seconds until the first collision between ship1 and ship2, or Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY if they never collide.
      double getX(IShip ship)
      Return the x-coordinate of ship.
      double getXVelocity(IShip ship)
      Return the velocity of ship along the X-axis.
      double getY(IShip ship)
      Return the y-coordinate of ship.
      double getYVelocity(IShip ship)
      Return the velocity of ship along the Y-axis.
      void move(IShip ship, double dt)
      Update ship's position, assuming it moves dt seconds at its current velocity.
      boolean overlap(IShip ship1, IShip ship2)
      Check whether ship1 and ship2 overlap.
      void thrust(IShip ship, double amount)
      Update ship's velocity based on its current velocity, its direction and the given amount.
      void turn(IShip ship, double angle)
      Update the direction of ship by adding angle (in radians) to its current direction.

    • Method Detail

      • createShip

        IShip createShip()
        Create a new ship with a default position, velocity, radius and direction. Result is a unit circle centered on (0, 0) facing right. Its speed is zero.

      • createShip

        IShip createShip(double x,
               double y,
               double xVelocity,
               double yVelocity,
               double radius,
               double angle)
        Create a new non-null ship with the given position, velocity, radius and angle (in radians).

      • getX

        double getX(IShip ship)
        Return the x-coordinate of ship.

      • getY

        double getY(IShip ship)
        Return the y-coordinate of ship.

      • getXVelocity

        double getXVelocity(IShip ship)
        Return the velocity of ship along the X-axis.

      • getYVelocity

        double getYVelocity(IShip ship)
        Return the velocity of ship along the Y-axis.

      • getRadius

        double getRadius(IShip ship)
        Return the radius of ship.

      • getDirection

        double getDirection(IShip ship)
        Return the direction of ship (in radians).

      • move

        void move(IShip ship,
        double dt)
        Update ship's position, assuming it moves dt seconds at its current velocity.

      • thrust

        void thrust(IShip ship,
          double amount)
        Update ship's velocity based on its current velocity, its direction and the given amount.

      • turn

        void turn(IShip ship,
        double angle)
        Update the direction of ship by adding angle (in radians) to its current direction. angle may be negative.

      • getDistanceBetween

        double getDistanceBetween(IShip ship1,
                        IShip ship2)
        Return the distance between ship1 and ship2. The absolute value of the result of this method is the minimum distance either ship should move such that both ships are adjacent. Note that the result must be negative if the ships overlap. The distance between a ship and itself is 0.

      • overlap

        boolean overlap(IShip ship1,
              IShip ship2)
        Check whether ship1 and ship2 overlap. A ship always overlaps with itself.

      • getTimeToCollision

        double getTimeToCollision(IShip ship1,
                        IShip ship2)
        Return the number of seconds until the first collision between ship1 and ship2, or Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY if they never collide. A ship never collides with itself.

      • getCollisionPosition

        double[] getCollisionPosition(IShip ship1,
                            IShip ship2)
        Return the first position where ship1 and ship2 collide, or null if they never collide. A ship never collides with itself. The result of this method is either null or an array of length 2, where the element at index 0 represents the x-coordinate and the element at index 1 represents the y-coordinate.
